questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

questions.text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asbestosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asbestosis is identified by the presence of characteristic asbestos bodies within the lung tissue, which are asbestos fibers coated with glycoproteins and hemosiderin, and it is commonly associated with asbestos exposure in occupational settings.
  • ➤ Asbestosis
  • ➤ asbestos bodies
  • ➤ asbestos exposure
  • ➤ Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1309
  • ➤ Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1309

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation? (AIIMS MAY 2021) Rolling Cytokine mediated integrin activation Adhesion Migration
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg. 103-104
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg. 103-104

questions.text: Match the following blood components with their shelf life: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The shelf life of blood components varies depending on their storage conditions and preservation methods. Here's a detailed explanation of the correct matches:
  • • Single donor platelets : Shelf life is 5 days when stored with continuous agitation to prevent clumping. This is essential to maintain the efficacy and viability of the platelets. Packed RBC : Shelf life is 42 days when stored in a preservative solution containing saline, adenine, glucose, and mannitol (SAGM). This extends the shelf life while maintaining the quality of the red blood cells. Cryoprecipitate : Shelf life is 1 year when stored at temperatures below -18°C. Cryoprecipitate is used for patients with clotting factor deficiencies, such as hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease. Granulocytes concentrate : Shelf life is 24 hours. This component contains white blood cells and is used for patients with severe neutropenia, such as those with febrile neutropenia or aplastic anemia.
  • • Single donor platelets : Shelf life is 5 days when stored with continuous agitation to prevent clumping. This is essential to maintain the efficacy and viability of the platelets.
  • • Single donor platelets
  • • Packed RBC : Shelf life is 42 days when stored in a preservative solution containing saline, adenine, glucose, and mannitol (SAGM). This extends the shelf life while maintaining the quality of the red blood cells.
  • • Packed RBC
  • • Cryoprecipitate : Shelf life is 1 year when stored at temperatures below -18°C. Cryoprecipitate is used for patients with clotting factor deficiencies, such as hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease.
  • • Cryoprecipitate
  • • Granulocytes concentrate : Shelf life is 24 hours. This component contains white blood cells and is used for patients with severe neutropenia, such as those with febrile neutropenia or aplastic anemia.
  • • Granulocytes concentrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Single donor platelets have a shelf life of 5 days, packed RBCs 42 days, cryoprecipitate 1 year, and granulocytes concentrate 24 hours.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for leukemia receives a blood transfusion. Shortly after the transfusion begins, he develops sudden-onset dyspnea, wheezing, and cyanosis. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Stop the blood transfusion and administer epinephrine

options.label: B
options.text: Continue the blood transfusion and monitor oxygen saturation

options.label: C
options.text: Administer corticosteroids and start oxygen therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop the blood transfusion and administer epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and administer epinephrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's sudden-onset dyspnea, wheezing, and cyanosis shortly after a blood transfusion indicate a severe allergic reaction, possibly an anaphylactic reaction. In such cases, the immediate and appropriate step is to stop the transfusion and administer epinephrine intramuscularly to counteract the life-threatening effects of the reaction. Epinephrine stabilizes mast cells, reduces airway edema, and improves circulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Continuing the blood transfusion despite signs of anaphylaxis is inappropriate and dangerous, as it could worsen the reaction.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Administering corticosteroids may help reduce inflammation in delayed reactions but is not the first-line treatment in acute anaphylaxis. Immediate epinephrine administration is critical.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Investigating clerical errors is important but not the priority during an acute, life-threatening reaction.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected anaphylactic reactions during blood transfusions, characterized by respiratory distress and systemic signs, the immediate management is to stop the transfusion and administer intramuscular epinephrine to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Membranous nephropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Membranous nephropathy is characterized by uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall with subepithelial immune deposits, as evidenced by the histological image provided.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, page no. 1766, 1767
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, page no. 1766, 1767

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a characteristic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) , confirming the diagnosis of this condition.
  • ➤ Birbeck granules
  • ➤ characteristic finding
  • ➤ Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH)
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition Pg 1168
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition Pg 1168

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IgE mediated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated and can occur on first exposure to the triggering substance, with NSAIDs being one of the common causes.
  • ➤ IgE-mediated

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schwannoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwannomas are benign nerve sheath tumors with distinct Antoni A and B growth patterns, including Verocay bodies. These features, along with the clinical presentation, are key to the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no - 2595
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no - 2595

questions.text: Philadelphia chromosome is caused by translocation of which of the following chromosomes? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 22 and 9

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Philadelphia chromosome, a hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t (9;22) (q34;q11). This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9, creating the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.
  • • t (9;22) (q34;q11).
  • • BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.
  • • The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, which is responsible for the uncontrolled proliferation and survival of myeloid cells in CML. The enhanced tyrosine kinase activity of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein leads to the development of this malignancy.
  • • The specific involvement of the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22 in the translocation can be denoted as t(9q;22q) or t(9;22)(q34;q11), where 'q' represents the long arm, and '34' and '11' represent the specific bands on the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, respectively, where the breakpoints occur.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Philadelphia chromosome, the hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22)(q34;q11). This translocation creates the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase responsible for the development of CML.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, malaise, and flank pain after a recent course of antibiotics for a sore throat. Urinalysis reveals pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts. There is no eosinophiluria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient’s symptoms of fever, malaise, flank pain, and the presence of pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts suggest pyelonephritis , a bacterial infection of the kidney parenchyma. The absence of eosinophiluria excludes tubulointerstitial nephritis in this case.
  • • pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts
  • • pyelonephritis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: Incorrect. While hematuria and RBC casts are typical of PSGN, it occurs after streptococcal infections and does not present with WBC casts or systemic symptoms like fever and flank pain as prominently as pyelonephritis.
  • • Option A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis:
  • • Option B. Tubulointerstitial nephritis: Incorrect. Tubulointerstitial nephritis is characterized by eosinophiluria, WBC casts, and a history of drug hypersensitivity. The absence of eosinophiluria makes this less likely.
  • • Option B. Tubulointerstitial nephritis:
  • • Option D. Lupus nephritis: Incorrect. Lupus nephritis involves immune-mediated glomerular damage, often with RBC casts and significant proteinuria. It typically occurs in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is not associated with WBC casts without other autoimmune signs.
  • • Option D. Lupus nephritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma and upper urinary tract. Key findings include pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts , along with systemic symptoms like fever and flank pain. It should be distinguished from other renal conditions based on clinical and laboratory features.
  • ➤ Pyelonephritis
  • ➤ pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with progressive weight loss and splenomegaly. His peripheral smear shows the presence of hairy cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to confirm the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining

questions.correct_answer: A. Bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of progressive weight loss, splenomegaly, and peripheral smear findings of hairy cells is suggestive of Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL). The definitive diagnostic test is a bone marrow biopsy, coupled with Tartrate-Resistant Acid Phosphatase (TRAP) staining, which shows positivity in hairy cells and is a classic hallmark of this disease. TRAP positivity confirms the diagnosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Flow cytometry is useful in confirming the immunophenotype of hairy cells (CD11c+, CD25+, CD103+), but it is not the definitive diagnostic test when TRAP staining can provide a direct confirmation.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Cytogenetics can provide additional insights into chromosomal abnormalities but is not required for primary diagnosis.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) may identify genetic alterations but is not the primary diagnostic tool for HCL.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient suspected of having Hairy Cell Leukemia, a bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining is the gold standard for diagnosis, as it directly identifies the characteristic features of hairy cells.

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented in OPD with hemoptysis. On examination, a hilar mass was noticed. The histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Primary effusion lymphoma is caused by which of the following viruses? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HHV 8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HHV 8 causes Castleman disease, Kaposi sarcoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in recognition and clearance of necrotic cells? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inflammasomes are crucial in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells by activating caspase-1 and inducing the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as triggering pyroptosis, an inflammatory form of cell death.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are commonly associated with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis, making them the likely antibody in patients presenting with features of both conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is diagnostic for mixed connective tissue disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by high titers of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP). This antibody is considered diagnostic for the condition, which presents with clinical features that overlap with those of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients typically present with synovitis of the fingers, Raynaud phenomenon, myositis, and renal involvement, which usually responds well to corticosteroids, at least in the short term.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody - While anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in mixed connective tissue disease, they are not specific for this condition. ANAs are found in many autoimmune diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and Sjögren syndrome, so their presence alone cannot differentiate mixed connective tissue disease from other connective tissue disorders.
  • • Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody
  • • Option B. SCL-70 antibody - SCL-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase I) is associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the diffuse cutaneous form with increased risk of pulmonary fibrosis and peripheral vascular disease. It is not characteristic of mixed connective tissue disease.
  • • Option B. SCL-70 antibody
  • • Option D. Anti-CCP antibody - Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not typically found in mixed connective tissue disease and are used to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of inflammatory arthritis.
  • • Option D. Anti-CCP antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High titres of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP) are the serological hallmark and diagnostic marker for mixed connective tissue disease, a condition with overlapping features of several autoimmune disorders including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conditions most commonly associated with Down's syndrome:
  • ➤ Conditions most commonly associated with Down's syndrome:
  • ➤ Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases) Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%) Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%) Hypothyroidism Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's) Epilepsy (in about 10%) Ocular disorders Reduced fertility Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)
  • ➤ Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • ➤ Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • ➤ Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • ➤ Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • ➤ Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism
  • ➤ Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • ➤ Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • ➤ Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • ➤ Ocular disorders
  • ➤ Reduced fertility
  • ➤ Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

questions.text: A patient presented with weight loss and malabsorption on eating specific food materials. She has been diagnosed with gluten sensitive enteropathy. Which of the following can be the safest food given to her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patients of gluten sensitive enteropathy should not be given the gluten rich cereals like BROW (Barley, Rye, Oat and Wheat) cereals or their derivatives like maida, sooji/semolina (as these are wheat products). So, the safest food for such patients would be rice.

questions.text: A case of complete gonadal dysgenesis was observed in a 46XY individual with female characteristics. The origin of complete gonadal dysgenesis lies in alterations of the SRY gene. What leads to complete gonadal dysgenesis in the SRY gene? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deletion of gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is primarily caused by the deletion of the SRY gene, which leads to a failure in the development of male gonads, resulting in female characteristics.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade by measuring the time it takes for plasma to clot after the addition of tissue thromboplastin and calcium. It is commonly prolonged in conditions such as vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, and the use of vitamin K antagonists.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic Basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg 232
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic Basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg 232

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The image represents chromosome 15, showing a deletion specifically on the maternal chromosome. Angelman syndrome is caused by the deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13.
  • • This genetic disorder is characterized by severe intellectual disability, speech impairment, ataxia, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent smiling and laughter. The primary causes of Angelman syndrome are maternal deletion and paternal uniparental disomy (paternal UPD), where two paternal chromosome copies are active, and the maternal copy is absent or silenced.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome : Prader-Willi syndrome results from a deletion of the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or maternal UPD. It presents with hypotonia, hyperphagia leading to obesity, and intellectual disability, which is different from Angelman syndrome.
  • • Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome
  • • Option C. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome : Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by epigenetic or genetic alterations involving chromosome 11p15, not chromosome 15. It is characterized by macrosomia, organomegaly, and an increased risk of embryonal tumors.
  • • Option C. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
  • • Option D. Edward syndrom e: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is caused by an extra chromosome 18 and does not involve deletions on chromosome 15. It presents with intellectual disability, heart defects, and distinct physical anomalies.
  • • Option D. Edward syndrom

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It is characterized by severe intellectual disability, a cheerful demeanor, and motor and speech impairments.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Russell bodies in plasma cells, along with a clinical history of intractable diarrhea, strongly suggests a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, a malignancy characterized by the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, Page No. 1126
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, Page No. 1126

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. What is the most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

questions.text: A patient with dyspnea, respiratory distress due to pan-acinar emphysema, and liver dysfunction is due to a likely defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver dysfunction due to a deficiency of the protective alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein.

questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Albumin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin
  • ➤ Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Allograft arteriopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allograft arteriopathy is the foremost long-term limitation in cardiac transplantation, causing significant morbidity and mortality through progressive coronary stenosis.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) BTK

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SCID is caused by mutations in several different genes
  • ➤ JAK3 RAG1 IL-7Ra
  • ➤ JAK3
  • ➤ JAK3
  • ➤ RAG1
  • ➤ RAG1
  • ➤ IL-7Ra
  • ➤ IL-7Ra
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg 438-439
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg 438-439

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th / 1081
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th / 1081

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever. The biopsy has revealed granulomatous necrotizing inflammation. Which of the following is the likely finding with this presentation? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels

options.label: B
options.text: Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels

options.label: C
options.text: Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels

options.label: D
options.text: Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels

questions.correct_answer: C. Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dystrophic calcification is a common finding in tissues undergoing necrosis, such as in caseating granulomas in tuberculosis, and it occurs with normal serum calcium levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a growth factor promoting proto-oncogene? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TGF-beta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TGF-beta is not a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes; instead, it is involved in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presents with fatigue, glossitis, and a burning sensation in his mouth. Peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Laboratory studies show normal vitamin B12 levels. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient’s symptoms, including fatigue and glossitis, along with the presence of macrocytic anemia (macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear) and low serum folate levels , strongly suggest folate deficiency .
  • • macrocytic anemia
  • • low serum folate levels
  • • folate deficiency
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Incorrect. Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, the absence of neurological symptoms (e.g., paresthesias, ataxia) and normal vitamin B12 levels make this less likely.
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency:
  • • Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency: Incorrect. Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with sideroblastic anemia, not megaloblastic anemia, and does not involve macrocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • • Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency:
  • • Option D. Niacin deficiency: Incorrect. Niacin deficiency presents as pellagra (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia), not megaloblastic anemia or glossitis with macrocytes.
  • • Option D. Niacin deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folate deficiency is a common cause of megaloblastic anemia and is characterized by macrocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils, and low serum folate levels. It typically presents with anemia and glossitis but lacks the neurological symptoms associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • ➤ Folate deficiency
  • ➤ megaloblastic anemia
  • ➤ anemia and glossitis

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian patient presented with weakness and reduced work capacity. He had a Hb of 10gm/dl and MCV-110. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In cases of anemia with high MCV, especially in vegetarians or those with dietary restrictions, megaloblastic anemia should be considered. Vitamin B12 and folate levels should be assessed to confirm the diagnosis, and dietary intake of these vitamins should be evaluated and corrected if deficient.

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an road traffic accident and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and Sp02 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transfusion reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), characterized by rapid onset of fever, bleeding from multiple sites, and hemolysis shortly after a blood transfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of intestinal inflammation? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) fecal lactoferrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation and is used to diagnose and monitor inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came with early satiety, massive splenomegaly, petechiae, and bleeding gums. Her hemoglobin was 8 gm/dl and TLC was 85,000/mm3. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CML

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) should be strongly suspected in a patient presenting with massive splenomegaly , early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance .
  • ➤ massive splenomegaly
  • ➤ early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance
  • ➤ The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, is the hallmark genetic abnormality in CML.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pelger-Huet Anomaly is false? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: B
options.text: Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia

options.label: C
options.text: Associated with normal survival of neutrophils

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pelger-Huet anomaly affects nuclear segmentation of neutrophils but does not impact platelet morphology; the abnormal hypo segmented neutrophils retain normal function and survival time in the hereditary form of the condition.

questions.text: Match the following microscopic finding with the type of tumor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? ( INICET MAY 2023) DiGeorge syndrome Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Complement deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.
  • ➤ However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.correct_answer: C. NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is primarily mediated by NK cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils, which kill target cells coated with antibodies through mechanisms that do not involve phagocytosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg no. 356
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg no. 356

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.correct_answer: C. Dystrophic with normal serum calcium
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg no 83
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg no 83

questions.text: All are true about Barrett esophagus except: (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD

options.label: C
options.text: Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.correct_answer: C. Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous cells to columnar cells, not squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), is a likely cause of scrotal swelling and ataxia due to its potential for extranodal involvement and associated paraneoplastic syndromes.
  • ➤ Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL),

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

questions.text: Organisms entering via enteric route into our body are countered by which cells of the liver? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kupffer cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kupffer cells are the liver macrophages responsible for countering organisms entering the body via the enteric route.

questions.text: A worker in an industry for the last 20 years develops dry cough and chest tightness. He had the following finding in his pulmonary biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Asbestosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asbestosis is characterized by the presence of asbestos bodies with a beaded or dumbbell appearance on lung biopsy, often seen in workers with long-term exposure to asbestos fibers.

questions.text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank? (AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank.

options.label: B
options.text: It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

options.label: C
options.text: No such time restraint and can be done anytime.

options.label: D
options.text: It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

questions.correct_answer: B. It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood transfusions must be completed within 4 hours of receiving the blood from the blood bank to minimize the risk of bacterial proliferation and ensure patient safety.
  • ➤ Blood transfusions must be completed within 4 hours of receiving the blood from the blood bank

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the esophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Image 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus typically occurs in the middle third of the esophagus and is characterized histologically by nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, as seen in Image 3.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1472, 1473
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1472, 1473

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 79, 1709
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ER+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Malakoplakia

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes with complaints of knee pain with the loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained which showed foreign body giant cells along with the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metallosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metallosis is a rare complication of joint replacement surgeries, characterized by the release of metallic debris from implants, leading to a foreign body reaction with the formation of foreign body giant cells and potential loosening of the implant.

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min

options.label: D
options.text: Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

questions.text: Zellballen pattern is not typically observed in which of the following tumors? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Zellballen pattern refers to a characteristic histological arrangement seen in paraganglionic tumors where neoplastic cells are arranged in nests or clusters separated by highly vascular fibrous septa. This is a hallmark finding in pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas. Pheochromocytomas are described as being "composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells and their supporting cells, compartmentalized into small nests by a rich vascular network" - this describes the Zellballen pattern. Paragangliomas occurring at sites like the carotid body share similar features, as they derive from paraganglionic tissues.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pheochromocytoma - This is incorrect because pheochromocytomas do exhibit the Zellballen pattern. Pheochromocytomas are characterized by "polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells and their supporting cells, compartmentalized into small nests by a rich vascular network," which describes the classic Zellballen arrangement.
  • • Option A. Pheochromocytoma
  • • Option B. Carotid Body Tumor - This is incorrect because carotid body tumors are paragangliomas that occur in the carotid body, a paraganglionic structure. These tumors show the same characteristic Zellballen pattern as pheochromocytomas because they derive from similar neural crest-derived tissue.
  • • Option B. Carotid Body Tumor
  • • Option D. Paraganglioma - This is incorrect because these tumours can demonstrate a pattern resembling Zellballen.
  • • Option D. Paraganglioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellballen pattern (nest-like arrangement of cells with rich intervascular stroma) is a characteristic histological feature of paraganglionic tumors like pheochromocytoma and carotid body tumors, but not of glioblastoma, which shows pseudopalisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Barrett’s esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition marked by intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells within the esophageal squamous mucosa, requiring regular surveillance for dysplasia and potential progression to adenocarcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Page No. 1464
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Page No. 1464
